title: Monday, 17th July, 2017

11:10 am
PM11:10am

What a disgusting and pathetic individual he [Paul Murphy] appears to be. I wonder what he has accomplished in his life! I have seen dozens of articles online in the last week but nothing remotely as nasty as this.
Most have been straight-forward and positive without cheap shots and sarcasm. I have read hundreds of pages on crypto. I can give you many reasons to buy (and sell).

PM11:11am

I will be complaining directly to FT and Alphaville about this. An apology from him is unacceptable. I worked 20 years to build a reputation and this miserable punk tries to damage it with his pen in five minutes.
I do not even know who he is or how he got on my email list. I have never spoken with him.
I am not ‘emboldened’, I ‘spammed’ no one; I did ‘not’ say Bitcoin would go to the moon; my target was for 2027; and I am not sure where in my piece there was ‘nutty’ advice.
What is strange here is that he actually gave attention to a piece he does not think is legitimate? Really?

PM11:11am

$50,000 on Bitcoin would be reached if crypto captured 1% of the $200 trillion currently in stocks, bonds, cash and gold by 2027. We are now at just 0.04%.
You could get a 25:1 payout here as Amazon, Google and Facebook investors received (but there is risk and volatility).

11:11 am
PM11:12am

Yeah, so if lots of people are stupid and sell stocks and buy buttcoin, the price will go up. Magic

PM11:12am

Nowadays, anyone can be a ‘contributor’ to these financial sites (and they get paid peanuts). You get what you pay for.
What a hatchet job. There are a lot of under-achieving and pathetic individuals in this world who feel better about themselves when they put others down.
He got paid to copy and paste my notes and added no color whatsoever of his own.

PM11:12am

And the pay off....

11:12 am
PM11:12am

I will contact Alphaville and FT immediately. And he is considered a journalist. My guess is that he was paid $100 for that ‘contributor’ submission.

11:17 am

PM11:17am

Have some snap commentary from Capital Economics

PM11:17am

Julian Evans-Pritchard

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Both the official GDP figures and our own measure of economic activity suggest growth held up well in Q2 but we don’t expect the strength to be sustained. GDP growth held steady at 6.9% y/y in Q2. Most had anticipated a slight decline (both the Bloomberg median and our forecast were 6.8%). We have doubts over the accuracy of the official figures, which point to implausibly stable growth in recent years. In contrast, our China Activity Proxy (CAP) showed a more pronounced recovery last year from a much deeper downturn in 2015. That said, growth does appear to have remained fairly stable last quarter at a rate close to what the official figures claim – our preliminary CAP estimates point to growth of 6.3% y/y in Q2, down from 6.5% in Q1.

PM11:18am

So Julian is sceptical.

PM11:18am

I think rightly so

11:18 am
PM11:18am

We have doubts over the accuracy of the official figures, which point to implausibly stable growth in recent years.

PM11:18am

What’s more, the economy appears to have ended Q2 on a strong note. Growth in industrial production and retail sales both accelerated in June. Year-to-date growth in fixed investment also stabilised, implying a pick-up in monthly terms. All three series beat consensus expectations. This strength seems unlikely to last, however. The recent crackdown on financial risks has driven a slowdown in credit growth, which will weigh on the economy during the second half of this year. What’s more, the National Financial Work Conference that concluded over the weekend has signalled that further regulatory tightening remains on the horizon.

PM11:19am

What's this Financial Work Conference thing?

11:18 am
PM11:19am

Missed that

PM11:19am

Ah, okay

PM11:19am

Have some Tao Wang on that

11:19 am
PM11:19am

UBS

PM11:19am

The Financial Work Conference (FWC) was held on July 14-15. President Xi stressed the importance of financial sector development and financial security, highlighting that "serving the real economy, prevent and contain financial risk, and deepen financial reform" as the three tasks for financial work over the coming years. By emphasising the need for financial services to "go back to the origin" of serving the real economy and the need to strengthen supervision, President Xi's speech implied that the ongoing drive to strengthen regulations and supervision on various shadow banking activities will continue (see Deleveraging by Supervisory Tightening and Preview for FWC ). We expect to see a more cohesive set of rules for various forms of financial services and asset management businesses in the coming couple of years.

PM11:19am

As expected, the FWC decided to establish a State Council Financial Stability and Development Commission to coordinate financial supervision and bridge any supervisory gaps. While no further details are yet available, the wording on enhancing PBC's role in macro-prudential management and preventing systematic risk suggests that perhaps the working office of the new commission will be set up in the central bank. We also expect the PBC to take a more prominent role in helping supervising systematically important financial institutions. Meanwhile, the new commission may be involved in or consulted with in monetary policy decisions as the latter would have implications for financial stability.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Reflecting concerns on high and rising leverage in the economy, the FWC called for 1) pushing for financial institutions to disclose truthfully and dispose timely bad assets; 2) continued deleveraging, with the focus on reducing leverage of state-owned enterprises and dealing with assets in "zombie companies"; and 3) strictly controlling new local government debt, establishing a life-time responsibility mechanism for local government debt. The last point implies that local government debt had continued to balloon in the past couple of years despite the new local debt management framework (see Understanding China (Part II) – How Serious Is China's Debt Problem?), and that recent tightening on local debt will likely continue (see Deleveraging by Supervisory Tightening: Enforcing Fiscal Rules).

PM11:20am

The FWC also called for developing capital markets, strengthening supervision for internet financing, encouraging development of small banks and private sector financing, among others in a comprehensive set of policy outlines.

While the FWC reiterated China's goal of opening financial markets, capital account liberalization and RMB internationalisation, it called for a gradual and stable approach in such moves and mentioned the need for "appropriate sequencing". This is in line with our expectations and indeed we do not foresee major opening moves related to the RMB or capital account in the near future.

PM11:20am

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,417, up 6 (+0.43%), High: 1,425, Low: 1,396, Volume: 863.91k
11:25 am
PM11:25am

Have some Shore

PM11:25am

Appointment of CEO. ITV had formally confirmed the much rumoured appointment of Carolyn McCall as it new CEO. Ms McCall will be known to may investors as the CEO of Easyjet – a role that she has held for seven years. From a Media perspective, she was previously CEO of Guardian Media Group. Ms McCall will take up her new role on 8 January 2018. The group will continue to be managed by a combination of its Chairman and very capable CFO, Ian Griffiths, in the meantime.

PM11:26am

We are reassured by this morning’s announcement given Ms McCall’s experience of running a major media business and leading the growth of an international FTSE 100 company. We also note her added experience as a non-exec of companies such as Tesco and Burberry.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Er...?

PM11:26am

More broadly we remain out positive stance on ITV ahead of its interim results on 26 July particularly In view of recent share price weakness which has given rise to valuation (FY17F and FY18F P/E and DY ratios of 10.7x 4.9% and 9.8x 5.4% respectively) which, in our view, is being weighed down by short-term concerns over advertising spend and overlooks its medium term attractions. The latter include: (a) an unrivalled ability to deliver a mass market commercial audience to advertisers via what is (in contrast to many digital platforms) a trusted and well understood medium; (b) the scale and commercial value of its content portfolio, and; (c) the prospect of solid EPS growth, a very attractive income progression (SCF three year aggregate DPS growth 39% excluding further “specials”), and strong cash generation (providing fuel for acquisitions, dividend growth / special payments, and de-leveraging an already under-geared balance sheet). We retain our Buy recommendation.

PM11:27am

Liberum also buyers

11:26 am
PM11:27am

As suggested in the press over the weekend, ITV has announced Carolyn McCall, CEO of Easyjet, as CEO. This appointment is likely to be taken positively given Ms McCall’s success at Easyjet over the past seven years. For ITV, we think the move suggests the company is comfortable with its strategic direction but her strong personal links should be helpful in several areas. ITV remains our top pick.

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:28am

Meanwhile, on the easyjet side...

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Positive news flow on multiple fronts

PM11:28am

Mark Simpson of Goodbody

PM11:28am

Breaking news since Friday afternoon represent two important developments for the carrier. Firstly, the airline indicated that it should shortly be issued an Air Operator Certificate (AOC) from Austro Control and an airline operating licence from the Austrian Ministry of Transport. This, in conjunction with its existing Swiss licence, would allow it to consolidate its intra-EU (non-UK touching) operations under a new company, easyJet Europe. Easyjet indicated that some 100 EU based aircraft and 4,000 employees based in six EU countries would form the basis of this new operation. While this will add some complexity and additional cost to the business, in does represent a significant step in overcoming the risk of the UK’s exit from the EU. Post this, the focus will be on the holdings in the company by post-Brexit non-EU investors, with the key development on this the potential treatment of the Haji-Ioannou Family’s 33.7% holding as registered in Cyprus rather than the UK.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

The second major piece of news is the resignation of CEO Carolyn McCall and the preview of this Thursday’s Q317 results. Carolyn McCall’s resignation, to take up the CEO role at ITV, follows a year of speculation as to her tenure following her discussions just over a year ago with Marks & Spencer’s. We feel that this is the right time for a change of senior management, with the need to address costs more aggressively than has been seen to date in the preand post-Brexit era. Attached to the statement were two paragraphs commenting on thisThursday release, withconfirmation that the Q3 yieldtrend is improving from prior quarters and that FY17 cost expectationsareto be up 1% yoy ex-fuel remain unchanged (again constant currency). With regards the yield commentarythis ‘improving trend’ couldstill be in line with their ‘single digit’ decline in Q3 CC yields, although given a positive currency impact our current forecast is for flat reported yields and -2.3% yoy on a cc basis.

PM11:29am

However, given that RYA’s Q118 to June could actually be up yoy vs the company’s previous -5% guidance, there is definitely scope for easyJet’s outrun to be better by a few ppts. In this instance, +2% vs our flat reported would equate to +25m on our current pre-tax forecast of £371m and suggests that the company could report FY17 pre-tax of over £400m.

PM11:29am

Done

PM11:31am

You didn't believe me on ZH recruiting at $$$$?

PM11:31am

My client is a controversial financial markets and news commentary service, that reports on any event which impacts on the financial markets, and aims to cut through all the noise. They are seeking a highly finically literate writer who can respond quickly to events as they happen. These could be anything from financial data on employment or municipal deficits to analysis of bubbles in debt markets or political events in Washington. Ideally you will have a background in finance, knowledge of how markets and economics work and the ability to write in an engaging way, getting to the core of a salutation in a concise manner. My client is not looking for someone who will look to their contacts for opinion on events but has the necessary understanding to be able read and comment on situations. They produce a daily blog so it’s necessary to be able to quickly write short, insightful articles in response to daily events. The package will include a good basic salary, generous bonus and healthcare plan. You will be joining a small team in a financially sound business, they are looking for someone who understands the need to produce copy that gets people’s attention but because you will be writing to a highly, financially literate audience it must have substance. This is not an easy job but the rewards are very high and if you have a passion for finance, the ability to write, and an in-depth understanding of finance and economics this job could be perfect.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Employer Sync Recruitment
Location New York City, New York (US)
Salary $100-200k + generous bonus
Posted Jul 13, 2017
Closes Aug 13, 2017

But I mention now cos of one of the weirdest stories this morning

11:39 am
PM11:39am

FRANKFURT (Reuters) - Europe's top banking regulator, the European Central Bank (ECB), is considering carrying out a special assessment of Deutsche Bank's (DBKGn.DE) two largest shareholders, a German paper reported on Sunday, citing regulatory sources.

The ECB may launch so-called ownership control procedures to scrutinize both the Qatari royal family and China's HNA (0521.HK), which each own just under 10 percent of the shares of Germany's flagship lender, Sueddeutsche Zeitung reported in a prereleased version of its Monday edition.

PM11:40am

The aim of a such an assessment is to establish whether an investor is trustworthy and financially sound, where the money used for the investment came from, and whether the investor engages in any criminal dealings such as money laundering or terrorist financing.

Normally it is only carried out if a shareholder holds more than 10 percent.

PM11:40am

The ECB is, however, for the first time considering using a possible exemption to the rule, which it can activate if it establishes that both Qatar and HNA exert significant influence on the bank despite owning a stake of less than 10 percent, the paper said.

Qatar, which has been a Deutsche Bank shareholder since 2014, and HNA, which acquired its stake this year, have each been granted a Deutsche Bank board seat.

Due to the generally low number of shareholders showing up at annual general meetings the two investors can factually block important decisions.

11:41 am

Why the hell is the ECB doing this?

PM11:41am

11:49 am
PM11:49am

If Press reports of Unilever attempting to acquire RB’s food business for £2bn are correct, it casts a question mark over Unilever’s strategic direction and financial discipline.

PM11:49am

The Sunday Times has reported that Unilever is attempting to buy RB’s food business in ‘a £2bn battle’; (it was announced by RB on 3rd April). It stresses that there’s a lot of competition. £2bn would equate to almost 17x our 2017E EBIT forecast and 4.7x 2017E sales. This feels like a full price for a business whose main asset is the French’s Mustard brand. The business has grown organically by 3%, 4% and 5% in 2014, 2015 and 2016, respectively, while an EBIT margin of 28.7% in 2016 is impressive, in our view, not least compared to the 17.9% earned by Unilever Food business last year.

PM11:49am

For RB this is a positive development, in our view, albeit insufficient to offset our concerns over the robustness of the business model and prospects for Mead Johnson. If Unilever is indeed pursuing this acquisition, we find it hard to reconcile with the noises it’s been making recently. For Unilever, we are concerned. The acquisition of a predominantly US-oriented ambient grocery business is difficult to reconcile with the HPC/emerging market direction that we believed Unilever intended to prioritise. And at almost 5x our 2017E sales it seems expensive.

11:50 am

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Tech mania, crypto, madness

PM11:57am

Sorry, I was sharing Rocket grey, wasn't I

PM11:58am

In our view, Rocket Internet’s primary goal this year was to try and bring their biggest holding, Hello Fresh, to IPO. Unfortunately, it would appear that there are two headwinds pressuring the same.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

First, the performance of closest rival Blue Apron's shares post-IPO. Having originally priced the offering at $15-$17/share the company priced the IPO at $10/share. 11 trading days after the IPO the stock is now
languishing -26% below the issue price. The market cap of Blue Apron is now $1.4B, significantly lower than the $2.1B valuation afforded two years ago on the last private funding round (series D), despite perceived significant growth since. The weak debut
doesn't bode well for Rocket's hope to bring Hello Fresh to the market. Blue Apron's revenue growth in 1Q17 (as per S-1 filing) was 42% YoY, similar to Hello Fresh's 40%. And this revenue growth remains driven by aggressive marketing spend. Here the metric
at Blue Apron is, in our view, rather alarming with F1Q17 marketing expenses growth at more than 3x revenue growth, increasing 138% YoY. We feel this is also reflective of low barriers to entry in the food kit market with the likes of Plated, chef’d, Purple
Carrot, Marley Spoon, Home Chef and Peach Dish also in the same space. Second, there appears there is a 600lb gorilla looming large on the horizon
– Amazon.

PM11:58am

Back in March Amazon quietly entered the meal kit market by partnering with Martha Stewart’s meal kits to offer the same to Amazon Fresh customers in four cities: New York, San Francisco, Philadelphia and Dallas.
Then in May, Tyson Food’s CEO said the company would partner with Amazon to offer Tyson Taste Makers later this year as a “line of chef inspired meal kits.” And now a report over the weekend in The Sunday Times suggests further developments in Amazon’s plans.
The paper reports that Amazon is stepping up its assault on America’s $780B grocery market with plans to deliver meal kits to customers’ homes. The internet retailer has registered a trademark in the US for a new service called “We do the prep. You be the
chef.” It will cover “prepared food kits . . . ready for assembly as a meal,” according to its application.

PM11:58am

Adding food kits to the Amazon Fresh solution enables a triple solution not possible with existing home kit solutions; adding it as an existing Amazon Fresh delivery is easy, satisfies food impulse for dinner that
day rather than requiring advanced planning and eliminates the huge and expensive shipping and packaging waste issue. Meal kits for Amazon can be expanded to its Amazon Go and Amazon Fresh Pickup bricks and mortar formats. The same gives the traditional supermarket
and food service industries yet another reason to fear Amazon.

11:58 am
PM11:59am

Given the intensifying competition, combined with the market’s reaction to peer Blue Apron, we feel the path to public life for Rocket’s Hello Fresh is looking unlikely. We remain sellers of Rocket Internet.

PM12:00pm

That's from Northern Trust

PM11:27am

We see Carolyn McCall’s strengths as very similar to those of outgoing CEO, Adam Crozier. She is seen as being very good with people, at building a strong management team around her and at the ability to “work the room”. She also has very good links on the Government side, which should be very helpful in areas such as retransmission revenues for ITV.

We would also not expect a major change in the strategy of ITV post-this appointment, which would suggest that ITV is comfortable both with the overall structural position of TV Broadcasters and that it has got its broad strategy (focus on building up content and new streams of revenues, plus Video on Demand etc.) right. The fact that Ian Griffiths, CFO and now also COO, remains also boosts this view.
